  <us-gaap:SignificantAccountingPoliciesTextBlock contextRef="c2_From1Jan2012To31Dec2012">&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;1.&#xd;
      Summary of Significant Accounting Policies&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;Basis&#xd;
      of Presentation&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;:&lt;/font&gt; &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;The financial statements have been&#xd;
      presented in a &amp;ldquo;development stage&amp;rdquo; format. Since&#xd;
      inception, our primary activities have been raising of&#xd;
      capital, obtaining financing and of obtaining route authority&#xd;
      and approval from the DOT and the FAA. We have not commenced&#xd;
      our principal revenue producing activities.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;Use&#xd;
      of Estimates:&lt;/font&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;The preparation of financial&#xd;
      statements in conformity with generally accepted accounting&#xd;
      principles requires our management to make estimates and&#xd;
      assumptions that affect reported amounts of assets and&#xd;
      liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and&#xd;
      liabilities at the date of the financial statement and the&#xd;
      reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the&#xd;
      reporting period. Actual results could differ from the&#xd;
      estimates.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;Cash&#xd;
      and Cash Equivalents:&lt;/font&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;For financial statement&#xd;
      presentation purposes, we consider those short-term, highly&#xd;
      liquid investments with original maturities of three months&#xd;
      or less to be cash or cash equivalents. There are no cash&#xd;
      equivalents at December 31, 2012 and 2011.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;Fair&#xd;
      Value of Financial Instruments:&lt;/font&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;FASB ASC 825, &amp;ldquo;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;Financial&#xd;
      Instruments&lt;/font&gt;&lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;,&amp;rdquo;&#xd;
      requires entities to disclose the fair value of financial&#xd;
      instruments, both assets and liabilities recognized and not&#xd;
      recognized on the balance sheet, for which it is practicable&#xd;
      to estimate fair value. FASB ASC 825 defines fair value of a&#xd;
      financial instrument as the amount at which the instrument&#xd;
      could be exchanged in a current transaction between willing&#xd;
      parties. At December&amp;nbsp;31, 2012 and 2011, the carrying&#xd;
      value of certain financial instruments (cash and cash&#xd;
      equivalents, accounts payable and accrued expenses.)&#xd;
      approximates fair value due to the short-term nature of the&#xd;
      instruments or interest rates, which are comparable with&#xd;
      current rates.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;Fair&#xd;
      Value Measurements:&lt;/font&gt; &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;FASB ASC 820 defines fair value&#xd;
      and establishes a framework for measuring fair value and&#xd;
      establishes a fair value hierarchy which prioritizes the&#xd;
      inputs to the inputs to the valuation techniques. Fair value&#xd;
      is the price that would be received to sell an asset or&#xd;
      amount paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction&#xd;
      between market participants at the measurement date. A fair&#xd;
      value measurement assumes that the transaction to sell the&#xd;
      asset or transfer the liability occurs in the principal&#xd;
      market for the asset or liability or, in the absence of a&#xd;
      principal market, the most advantageous market. Valuation&#xd;
      techniques that are consistent with the market, income or&#xd;
      cost approach, as specified by FASB ASC 820, are used to&#xd;
      measure fair value.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;Fair&#xd;
      Value Hierarchy:&lt;/font&gt; &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;FASB&#xd;
      ASC 820 specifies a hierarchy of valuation techniques based&#xd;
      upon whether the inputs to those valuation techniques reflect&#xd;
      assumptions other market participants would use based upon&#xd;
      market data obtained from independent sources (observable&#xd;
      inputs), or reflect the Company&amp;rsquo;s own assumptions of&#xd;
      market participant valuation (unobservable inputs). In&#xd;
      accordance with FASB ASC 820, these two types of inputs have&#xd;
      created the following fair value hierarchy:&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;table style=&quot;border-spacing: 0px; border-collapse: collapse; width: 95.84%; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;tr&gt;&#xd;
        &lt;td style=&quot;width: 27.0pt; background-color: #auto;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
          &lt;div style=&quot;text-align: right;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
            &lt;font style=&quot;font-family: Symbol; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&amp;#61623;&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
          &lt;/div&gt;&#xd;
        &lt;/td&gt;&#xd;
        &lt;td style=&quot;width: 387.0pt; background-color: #auto;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
          &lt;div&gt;&#xd;
            &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;Level 1 &amp;ndash; Quoted&#xd;
            prices in active markets that are unadjusted and&#xd;
            accessible at the measurement date for identical,&#xd;
            unrestricted assets or liabilities.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
          &lt;/div&gt;&#xd;
        &lt;/td&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;/tr&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;tr&gt;&#xd;
        &lt;td style=&quot;background-color: #auto;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
          &lt;div style=&quot;text-align: right;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
            &lt;font style=&quot;font-family: Symbol; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&amp;#61623;&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
          &lt;/div&gt;&#xd;
        &lt;/td&gt;&#xd;
        &lt;td style=&quot;background-color: #auto;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
          &lt;div&gt;&#xd;
            &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;Level 2 &amp;ndash; Quoted&#xd;
            prices for identical assets and liabilities in markets&#xd;
            that are not active, quoted prices for similar assets&#xd;
            and liabilities in active markets or financial&#xd;
            instruments for which significant inputs are&#xd;
            observable, either directly or indirectly.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
          &lt;/div&gt;&#xd;
        &lt;/td&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;/tr&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;tr&gt;&#xd;
        &lt;td style=&quot;background-color: #auto;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
          &lt;div style=&quot;text-align: right;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
            &lt;font style=&quot;font-family: Symbol; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&amp;#61623;&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
          &lt;/div&gt;&#xd;
        &lt;/td&gt;&#xd;
        &lt;td style=&quot;background-color: #auto;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
          &lt;div&gt;&#xd;
            &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;Level 3 &amp;ndash; Prices&#xd;
            or valuations that require inputs that are both&#xd;
            significant to the fair value measurement and&#xd;
            unobservable.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
          &lt;/div&gt;&#xd;
        &lt;/td&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;/tr&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/table&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;FASB ASC 820 requires the&#xd;
      use of observable market data if such data is available&#xd;
      without undue cost and effort.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font&gt;F-6&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center; font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;BALTIA&#xd;
      AIR LINES, INC. NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center; font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;DECEMBER&#xd;
      31, 2012&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;1.&#xd;
      Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (continued)&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;Measurement of Fair&#xd;
      Value&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;The Company&#xd;
      measures fair value as an exit price using the procedures&#xd;
      described below for all assets and liabilities measured at&#xd;
      fair value. When available, the Company uses unadjusted&#xd;
      quoted market prices to measure fair value and classifies&#xd;
      such items within Level 1. If quoted market prices are not&#xd;
      available, fair value is based upon internally developed&#xd;
      models that use, where possible, current market-based or&#xd;
      independently-sourced market parameters such as interest&#xd;
      rates and currency rates. Items valued using internally&#xd;
      generated models are classified according to the lowest level&#xd;
      input or value driver that is significant to the valuation.&#xd;
      Thus, an item may be classified in Level 3 even though there&#xd;
      may be inputs that are readily observable. If quoted market&#xd;
      prices are not available, the valuation model used generally&#xd;
      depends on the specific asset or liability being valued. The&#xd;
      determination of fair value considers various factors&#xd;
      including interest rate yield curves and time value&#xd;
      underlying the financial instruments.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;Property&#xd;
      and Equipment:&lt;/font&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;Property and equipment are&#xd;
      recorded at cost. Depreciation is computed using the&#xd;
      straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the&#xd;
      assets, generally 5-15 years. Expenditures for renewals and&#xd;
      betterments are capitalized. Expenditures for minor items,&#xd;
      repairs and maintenance are charged to operations as&#xd;
      incurred. Gain or loss upon sale or retirement due to&#xd;
      obsolescence is reflected in the operating results in the&#xd;
      period the event takes place.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;Valuation&#xd;
      of Long-Lived Assets:&lt;/font&gt; &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;We review the recoverability of&#xd;
      our long-lived assets, including buildings, equipment and&#xd;
      intangible assets, when events or changes in circumstances&#xd;
      occur that indicate that the carrying value of the asset may&#xd;
      not be recoverable. The assessment of possible impairment is&#xd;
      based on our ability to recover the carrying value of the&#xd;
      asset from the expected future pre-tax cash flows&#xd;
      (undiscounted and without interest charges) of the related&#xd;
      operations. If these cash flows are less than the carrying&#xd;
      value of such asset, an impairment loss is recognized for the&#xd;
      difference between estimated fair value and carrying value.&#xd;
      Our primary measure of fair value is based on discounted cash&#xd;
      flows. The measurement of impairment requires management to&#xd;
      make estimates of these cash flows related to long-lived&#xd;
      assets, as well as other fair value determinations.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;a id=&quot;exp1&quot; name=&quot;exp1&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;We amortize the costs of other&#xd;
      intangibles (excluding goodwill) over their estimated useful&#xd;
      lives unless such lives are deemed indefinite. Amortizable&#xd;
      intangible assets are tested for impairment based on&#xd;
      undiscounted cash flows and, if impaired, written down to&#xd;
      fair value based on either discounted cash flows or appraised&#xd;
      values. Intangible assets with indefinite lives are tested&#xd;
      for impairment, at least annually, and written down to fair&#xd;
      value as required.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 5.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;Stock-Based&#xd;
      Compensation Plans:&lt;/font&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;Stock-based awards are accounted&#xd;
      for using the fair value method in accordance with ASC&#xd;
      718,&lt;/font&gt; &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;Share-Based&#xd;
      Payments.&lt;/font&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;Our&#xd;
      primary type of share-based compensation consists of stock&#xd;
      options. We use the Black-Scholes option pricing model in&#xd;
      valuing options. The inputs for the valuation analysis of the&#xd;
      options include the market value of the Company&amp;rsquo;s&#xd;
      common stock, the estimated volatility of the Company&amp;rsquo;s&#xd;
      common stock, the exercise price of the warrants and the risk&#xd;
      free interest rate.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center; font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font&gt;F-7&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center; font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;BALTIA&#xd;
      AIR LINES, INC. NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center; font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;DECEMBER&#xd;
      31, 2012&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;1.&#xd;
      Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (continued)&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;Earnings&#xd;
      per Common Share:&lt;/font&gt; &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;Basic earnings per share is&#xd;
      computed by dividing income available to common shareholders&#xd;
      (the numerator) by the weighted-average number of common&#xd;
      shares outstanding (the denominator) for the period. Diluted&#xd;
      earnings per share assume that any dilutive convertible&#xd;
      securities outstanding were converted, with related preferred&#xd;
      stock dividend requirements and outstanding common shares&#xd;
      adjusted accordingly. It also assumes that outstanding common&#xd;
      shares were increased by shares issuable upon exercise of&#xd;
      those stock options for which market price exceeds the&#xd;
      exercise price, less shares which could have been purchased&#xd;
      by us with the related proceeds. In periods of losses,&#xd;
      diluted loss per share is computed on the same basis as basic&#xd;
      loss per share as the inclusion of any other potential shares&#xd;
      outstanding would be anti-dilutive.&amp;nbsp;All options have&#xd;
      either expired or been cancelled during 2012. No adjustment&#xd;
      has been made to the weighted-average number of shares&#xd;
      outstanding in the calculation of earnings per share. For&#xd;
      2011, the earnings per share calculation excluded options of&#xd;
      5,556,818 because they were anti-dilutive.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 5.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;Income&#xd;
      Taxes:&lt;/font&gt; &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;We have&#xd;
      adopted ASC 740,&lt;/font&gt; &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;Accounting for&#xd;
      Income Taxes.&lt;/font&gt; &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;Pursuant to ASC 740, we are&#xd;
      required to compute tax asset benefits for net operating&#xd;
      losses carried forward. The potential benefits of net&#xd;
      operating losses have not been recognized in these financial&#xd;
      statements because the Company cannot be assured it is more&#xd;
      likely than not it will utilize the net operating losses&#xd;
      carried forward in future years.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 5.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;We must make certain&#xd;
      estimates and judgments in determining income tax expense for&#xd;
      financial statement purposes. These estimates and judgments&#xd;
      occur in the calculation of certain tax assets and&#xd;
      liabilities, which arise from differences in the timing of&#xd;
      recognition of revenue and expense for tax and financial&#xd;
      statement purposes.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;Deferred tax assets and&#xd;
      liabilities are determined based on the differences between&#xd;
      financial reporting and the tax basis of assets and&#xd;
      liabilities using the tax rates and laws in effect when the&#xd;
      differences are expected to reverse. ASC 740 provides for the&#xd;
      recognition of deferred tax assets if realization of such&#xd;
      assets is more likely than not to occur. Realization of our&#xd;
      net deferred tax assets is dependent upon our generating&#xd;
      sufficient taxable income in future years in appropriate tax&#xd;
      jurisdictions to realize benefit from the reversal of&#xd;
      temporary differences and from net operating loss, or NOL,&#xd;
      carryforwards. We have determined it more likely than not&#xd;
      that these timing differences will not materialize and have&#xd;
      provided a valuation allowance against substantially all of&#xd;
      our net deferred tax asset. Management will continue to&#xd;
      evaluate the realizability of the deferred tax asset and its&#xd;
      related valuation allowance. If our assessment of the&#xd;
      deferred tax assets or the corresponding valuation allowance&#xd;
      were to change, we would record the related adjustment to&#xd;
      income during the period in which we make the determination.&#xd;
      Our tax rate may also vary based on our results and the mix&#xd;
      of income or loss in domestic and foreign tax jurisdictions&#xd;
      in which we operate.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; color: #454545;&quot;&gt;Effective&#xd;
      January 1, 2007, the Company adopted FASB guidelines that&#xd;
      address the determination of whether tax benefits claimed or&#xd;
      expected to be claimed on a tax return should be recorded in&#xd;
      the financial statements. Under this guidance, we may&#xd;
      recognize the tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only&#xd;
      if it is more likely than not that the tax position will be&#xd;
      sustained on examination by the taxing authorities, based on&#xd;
      the technical merits of the position. The tax benefits&#xd;
      recognized in the financial statements from such a position&#xd;
      should be measured based on the largest benefit that has a&#xd;
      greater than fifty percent likelihood of being realized upon&#xd;
      ultimate settlement. This guidance also provides guidance on&#xd;
      derecognition, classification, interest and penalties on&#xd;
      income taxes, accounting in interim periods and requires&#xd;
      increased disclosures. At the date of adoption, and as of&#xd;
      December 31, 2012 and 2011, the Company did not have a&#xd;
      liability for unrecognized tax benefits, and no adjustment&#xd;
      was required at adoption.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; color: #454545;&quot;&gt;The&#xd;
      Company&amp;rsquo;s policy is to record interest and penalties on&#xd;
      uncertain tax provisions as income tax expense. As of&#xd;
      December 31, 2012 and 2011, the Company has not accrued&#xd;
      interest or penalties related to uncertain tax positions.&#xd;
      Additionally, tax years 2007 through 2012 remain open to&#xd;
      examination by the major taxing jurisdictions to which the&#xd;
      Company is subject.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; color: #454545;&quot;&gt;Upon the&#xd;
      attainment of taxable income by the Company, management will&#xd;
      assess the likelihood of realizing the tax benefit associated&#xd;
      with the use of the carryforwards and will recognize a&#xd;
      deferred tax asset at that time.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center; font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;F-8&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center; font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;BALTIA&#xd;
      AIR LINES, INC. NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center; font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;DECEMBER&#xd;
      31, 2012&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;1.&#xd;
      Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (continued)&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;Recent&#xd;
      Accounting Pronouncements:&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 5.0pt; margin-top: 5.0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;Recently&#xd;
      Adopted Standards&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;Liabilities.&amp;rdquo; This ASU&#xd;
      requires an entity to disclose information about offsetting&#xd;
      and related arrangements to enable users of its financial&#xd;
      statements to understand the effect of those arrangements on&#xd;
      its financial position. ASU No. 2011-11 will be applied&#xd;
      retrospectively and is effective for annual and interim&#xd;
      reporting periods beginning on or after January 1, 2013. The&#xd;
      Company does not expect adoption of this standard to have a&#xd;
      material impact on its results of operations, financial&#xd;
      condition, or liquidity.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;Other recent accounting&#xd;
      pronouncements issued by the FASB (including its Emerging&#xd;
      Issues Task Force), the AICPA, and the Securities Exchange&#xd;
      Commission (the &quot;SEC&quot;) did not or are not believed by&#xd;
      management to have a material impact on the Company&apos;s present&#xd;
      or future financial statements.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;</us-gaap:SignificantAccountingPoliciesTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:NatureOfOperations contextRef="c2_From1Jan2012To31Dec2012">&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;2.&#xd;
      Organization and Operations&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 5.0pt; margin-top: 5.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;a id=&quot;exp40&quot; name=&quot;exp40&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a id=&quot;exp41&quot; name=&quot;exp41&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;The Company&#xd;
      was formed as a U.S. airline on August 24, 1989 in the State&#xd;
      of New York. Our objective is to provide scheduled air&#xd;
      transportation from the U.S. to Russia, the Baltic States and&#xd;
      Ukraine. In 1991, the Department of Transportation (DOT)&#xd;
      granted the Company routes to provide non-stop passenger,&#xd;
      cargo and mail service from JFK to St. Petersburg and from&#xd;
      JFK to Riga, with online service to Minsk, Kiev and Tbilisi&#xd;
      as well as back up service to Moscow. We have two registered&#xd;
      trademarks &quot;BALTIA&quot; and &quot;VOYAGER CLASS,&quot; and five trademarks&#xd;
      subject to registration. Our activities to date have been&#xd;
      devoted principally to raising capital, obtaining route&#xd;
      authority and approval from the DOT and the FAA, training&#xd;
      crews, and conducting market research to develop the&#xd;
      Company&apos;s marketing strategy.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: justify; font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;Regulatory&#xd;
      Compliance&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;We intend to&#xd;
      operate as a Part 121 carrier, a heavy jet operator. As such,&#xd;
      following certification we will be required to maintain our&#xd;
      air carrier standards as prescribed by DOT and FAA regulation&#xd;
      and as specified in the FAA approved Company manuals. As part&#xd;
      of its regulatory compliance we will be required to submit&#xd;
      periodic reports of our operations to the DOT.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;</us-gaap:NatureOfOperations>
  <us-gaap:SegmentReportingDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="c2_From1Jan2012To31Dec2012">&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;

        &lt;/td&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;/tr&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;tr&gt;&#xd;
        &lt;td style=&quot;background-color: #auto;&quot;&gt;&#xd;

  <us-gaap:StockholdersEquityPolicyTextBlock contextRef="c2_From1Jan2012To31Dec2012">&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;4.&#xd;
      Stockholders&apos; Equity&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;Description of&#xd;
      Securities&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;Common&#xd;
      Stock:&lt;/font&gt; &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;We have&#xd;
      2,850,000,000&amp;nbsp;authorized shares of Common Stock at&#xd;
      $.0001 par value per share. As of&lt;/font&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;December 31, 2012, a total of&#xd;
      2,464,456,384 shares of Common Stock were&lt;/font&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;issued and outstanding and held by&#xd;
      over 1000 shareholders. Holders of Common Stock are entitled&#xd;
      to receive&lt;/font&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;dividends, when and if declared by&#xd;
      the board of directors, subject to prior rights of holders of&#xd;
      any Preferred Stock then outstanding and to share ratably in&#xd;
      the net assets of the company upon liquidation. Holders of&#xd;
      Common Stock do not have preemptive or other rights to&#xd;
      subscribe&lt;/font&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;for&#xd;
      additional shares. The Certificate of Incorporation does not&#xd;
      provide for cumulative voting. Shares of&lt;/font&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;Common Stock have equal voting,&#xd;
      dividend, liquidation and other rights, and have no&#xd;
      preference, exchange or appraisal rights.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;Preferred&#xd;
      Stock:&lt;/font&gt; &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;We are&#xd;
      authorized to issue up to a maximum of 2 million shares&#xd;
      (66,500 shares outstanding) of Preferred Stock. We can issue&#xd;
      these shares as our board of directors shall from time to&#xd;
      time fix by resolution. Our Preferred Stock is not entitled&#xd;
      to share in any dividends declared on the Common Stock and&#xd;
      has no voting rights. Each share is convertible in to 3&#xd;
      shares of Common. The liquidation preference is set by this&#xd;
      conversion formula and results in a pro rata claim on the&#xd;
      Company&amp;rsquo;s assets based upon the underlying common&#xd;
      shares issuable (199,500) upon conversion.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;Recent&#xd;
      Issuance of Unregistered Securities&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;2012:&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 5.0pt; margin-top: 5.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;

    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 5.0pt; margin-top: 5.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;

  <us-gaap:IncomeTaxDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="c2_From1Jan2012To31Dec2012">&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;5. Income&#xd;
      Taxes&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;The Company has&#xd;
      approximately $30.8 million in available net operating loss&#xd;
      carryovers available to reduce future income taxes. These&#xd;
      carryovers expire at various dates through the year 2032. The&#xd;
      Company has adopted ASC 740,&lt;/font&gt; &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-style: italic;&quot;&gt;Accounting for&#xd;
      Income Taxes&lt;/font&gt; &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;which&#xd;
      provides for the recognition of a deferred tax asset based&#xd;
      upon the value the loss carry-forwards will have to reduce&#xd;
      future income taxes and management&apos;s estimate of the&#xd;
      probability of the realization of these tax benefits. We have&#xd;
      determined it more likely than not that these timing&#xd;
      differences will not materialize and have provided a&#xd;
      valuation allowance against our entire net deferred tax asset&#xd;
      of approximately $6.1 million.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;Utilization of federal and&#xd;
      state NOL and tax credit carry-forwards may be subject to a&#xd;
      substantial annual limitation due to the ownership change&#xd;
      limitations provided by the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as&#xd;
      amended, and similar state provisions. The annual limitation&#xd;
      may result in the expiration of NOL and tax credit&#xd;
      carry-forwards before full utilization.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;</us-gaap:IncomeTaxDisclosureTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:CommitmentsAndContingenciesDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="c2_From1Jan2012To31Dec2012">&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;

    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;margin-bottom: 5.0pt; margin-top: 5.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;

      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;The Company leases office&#xd;
      space for its administrative offices, under three month to&#xd;
      month agreements, at a combined monthly rental of&#xd;
      approximately $27,000. In 2012 and 2011 expense was $618,544&#xd;
      and $336,979 respectively.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;</us-gaap:CommitmentsAndContingenciesDisclosureTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:RelatedPartyTransactionsDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="c2_From1Jan2012To31Dec2012">&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;7.&#xd;
      Long-Term Debt-Related Party:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;On December 1, 2010, the&#xd;
      Company entered into a loan arrangement with a company owned&#xd;
      or controlled by one of our directors for a total amount of&#xd;
      $1,150,000. The Company issued a note bearing interest at 9%&#xd;
      per annum payable quarterly and a maturity date of March 31,&#xd;
      2013. The Company will be obligated to repay the note prior&#xd;
      to the maturity date upon raising $4 million or from the&#xd;
      proceeds of operating revenue. As a loan inducement the&#xd;
      Company issued 6.8 million shares of common stock and 3.4&#xd;
      million warrants. A placement fee of $50,000 was paid from&#xd;
      the proceeds of this loan. The note is secured by both&#xd;
      aircraft up to a limit of $2.9 million.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;a id=&quot;jump_exp_1&quot; name=&quot;jump_exp_1&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a id=&quot;jump_exp_2&quot; name=&quot;jump_exp_2&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;The&#xd;
      Company recorded the relative fair value of the shares and&#xd;
      warrants of $294,297 as additional paid-in capital and&#xd;
      established a discount on the debt. The discount is being&#xd;
      amortized over the life of the note (27&amp;nbsp;months) at an&#xd;
      effective rate of 14.98%. The note is carried net of the&#xd;
      discount.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;</us-gaap:RelatedPartyTransactionsDisclosureTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:OrganizationConsolidationAndPresentationOfFinancialStatementsDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="c2_From1Jan2012To31Dec2012">&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;8.&#xd;
      Management&apos;s Plan of Operation&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;We believe we currently have&#xd;
      sufficient capital to commence revenue flight operations and&#xd;
      to maintain our current level of operations. During 2012 and&#xd;
      into 2013 we continue to finance our operations through the&#xd;
      issuance of our common stock and the continued exercise of&#xd;
      warrants. Until revenue operations begin, our monthly&#xd;
      expenditures for administrative and regulatory compliance can&#xd;
      be controlled at about $200,000-$400,000.&amp;nbsp; Based on&#xd;
      current reserves we have sufficient capital to support our&#xd;
      development stage operations through the most of 2013.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;In 2012 we raised $3.6&#xd;
      million in a private placement in order to start revenue&#xd;
      flight operations. Based on our prior experience with&#xd;
      certification and current preparations the management&#xd;
      believes that the launch budget, previously reviewed by the&#xd;
      DOT, will be adequate to complete certification and to&#xd;
      commence flight service. Approximately $300,000 is budgeted&#xd;
      for aircraft, $450,000 for certification tasks, and $300,000&#xd;
      for general and administrative expenses. At the time flight&#xd;
      service is inaugurated the company plans to have&#xd;
      approximately 15 management and 45 staff&#xd;
      personnel.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;Management has considered&#xd;
      the overall pipeline effect that enhances the initial cash&#xd;
      position of a startup carrier. It is the industry practice&#xd;
      for passengers to purchase tickets in advance of their&#xd;
      flights while service vendors bill the carrier later.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;In order that a new airline&#xd;
      would not fly empty on day one, approximately 30 days prior&#xd;
      to the expected inaugural date the DOT authorizes sales of&#xd;
      tickets and cargo. Such funds from advance sales, estimated&#xd;
      at approximately $3 mm for the company, accumulate in an&#xd;
      escrow account, and are released upon the issuance of the air&#xd;
      carrier certificate.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;There can be no assurance&#xd;
      that additional financing will be available on terms&#xd;
      favorable to us or at all. If adequate funds are not&#xd;
      available or are not available on acceptable terms, we may&#xd;
      not be able to fund expansion.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;</us-gaap:OrganizationConsolidationAndPresentationOfFinancialStatementsDisclosureTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:LiquidityDisclosureGoingConcernNote contextRef="c2_From1Jan2012To31Dec2012">&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;9. Going&#xd;
      Concern&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;The accompanying financial&#xd;
      statements have been prepared assuming that the company will&#xd;
      continue as a going concern, which contemplates the&#xd;
      recoverability of assets and the satisfaction of liabilities&#xd;
      in the normal course of business. Currently, the Company has&#xd;
      a minimum cash balance available for the payment of ongoing&#xd;
      operating expenses, and its operations has not of yet&#xd;
      produced any revenue, which would allow it to cover its&#xd;
      operational costs and allow it to continue as a going&#xd;
      concern. Since inception, the Company has incurred a deficit&#xd;
      during its development stage of approximately $88.0 million&#xd;
      and consumed approximately $21.0 million. The continued&#xd;
      operations of the Company is dependent upon implementing&#xd;
      airline service that would generate profits and raising&#xd;
      sufficient capital through placement of its common stock or&#xd;
      issuance of debt securities, which would enable the Company&#xd;
      to carry out its business plan.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;In the event we do not&#xd;
      generate sufficient funds from revenues or financing through&#xd;
      the issuance of our common stock or from debt financing, we&#xd;
      may be unable to fully implement our business plan and pay&#xd;
      our obligations as they become due, any of which&#xd;
      circumstances would have a material adverse effect on our&#xd;
      business prospects, financial condition, and results of&#xd;
      operations. The accompanying financial statements do not&#xd;
      include any adjustments that might be required should the&#xd;
      Company be unable to recover the value of its assets or&#xd;
      satisfy its liabilities.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;During 2012 and into 2011,&#xd;
      we continue to finance our operations through the issuance of&#xd;
      our common stock and the continued exercise of warrants.&#xd;
      Until revenue operations begin, our monthly expenditures for&#xd;
      administrative and regulatory compliance can be controlled at&#xd;
      about $200,000-$400,000.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;In 2012, we raised $3.6&#xd;
      million a private placement in order to start revenue flight&#xd;
      operations. Revenue services did not start in 2011 as&#xd;
      planned, and, as of April 15, 2013, we still have not&#xd;
      implemented revenue producing services. At the time flight&#xd;
      service is inaugurated, the company plans to have&#xd;
      approximately 15 management and 45 staff personnel.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;Management has considered&#xd;
      the overall pipeline effect that enhances the initial cash&#xd;
      position of a startup carrier. It is the industry practice&#xd;
      for passengers to purchase tickets in advance of their&#xd;
      flights while service vendors bill the carrier later.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;In order that a new airline&#xd;
      would not fly empty on day one, approximately 30 days prior&#xd;
      to the expected inaugural date the DOT authorizes sales of&#xd;
      tickets and cargo. Such funds from advance sales, estimated&#xd;
      at approximately $3 million for the company, accumulate in an&#xd;
      escrow account, and are released upon the issuance of the air&#xd;
      carrier certificate.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;There can be no assurance&#xd;
      that additional financing will be available on terms&#xd;
      favorable to us or at all. If adequate funds are not&#xd;
      available or are not available on acceptable terms, we may&#xd;
      not be able to fund expansion.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;</us-gaap:LiquidityDisclosureGoingConcernNote>
  <us-gaap:PensionAndOtherPostretirementBenefitsDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="c2_From1Jan2012To31Dec2012">&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;10.&#xd;
      Related Party&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;During the year ended&#xd;
      December 31, 2012 and 2011, the Company issued 194,000,000&#xd;
      and 245,749,998, respectively, restricted shares of its&#xd;
      $0.001 par value common stock to officers and directors.&#xd;
      These restricted shares were valued at $5,131,000 and&#xd;
      $12,714,000, respectively, or a weighted average price of&#xd;
      approximately $0.026 and $0.50 per share, respectively. Its&#xd;
      president and CEO was charged additional compensation of&#xd;
      $15,000 and $15,000, which represents one hundred percent of&#xd;
      the rent the Company paid for its original corporate&#xd;
      headquarters during the years ended December 31, 2012 and&#xd;
      2011, respectively. Also, during the years ended December 31,&#xd;
      2012 and 2011, this officer received other compensation of&#xd;
      $35,957 and $60,106, respectively, for services provided the&#xd;
      Company in lieu of salary. A second officer, Vice President&#xd;
      &amp;ndash; Finance, was paid additional compensation of $198,285&#xd;
      and $347,948 for the years ended December 31, 2012 and 2011,&#xd;
      respectively, which represents amounts paid him for&#xd;
      negotiating services in connection with the raise of new&#xd;
      equity capital. A third officer, Vice President, was paid&#xd;
      additional compensation of $30,500 and $51,000 for services&#xd;
      provided the Company during the years ended December 31, 2012&#xd;
      and 2011, respectively. A fourth officer, Corporate&#xd;
      Secretary, was additional compensation of $15,960 for&#xd;
      services provided the Company during the year ended December&#xd;
      31, 2012.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;</us-gaap:PensionAndOtherPostretirementBenefitsDisclosureTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:SubsequentEventsTextBlock contextRef="c2_From1Jan2012To31Dec2012">&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: 12.0pt; font-family: Times New Roman;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt; font-weight: bold;&quot;&gt;11.&#xd;
      Subsequent events&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;The Company has successfully&#xd;
      completed Gate I requirements of FAA Air Carrier&#xd;
      Certification process&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;On March 28, 2013, at the&#xd;
      FAA East Michigan Flight Standards District Office Baltia Air&#xd;
      Lines senior staff and their FAA counterparts conducted a&#xd;
      Formal Meeting to review Baltia&amp;rsquo;s certification&#xd;
      documentation and management readiness.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;On April 10, 2013, Baltia&#xd;
      received confirmation that Baltia&amp;rsquo;s management&#xd;
      personnel, system design, and other supporting documentation&#xd;
      were found to be satisfactory.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;&#xd;
      &lt;font style=&quot;font-size: 10.0pt;&quot;&gt;The FAA Certification Team&#xd;
      has determined that Baltia meets the requirements of FAA&#xd;
      Order 8900.1 Volume 10 Chapter 2 Section 6 and is fit to&#xd;
      enter into Phase II of the ATOS Certification Process.&lt;/font&gt;&#xd;
    &lt;/div&gt;&lt;br/&gt;</us-gaap:SubsequentEventsTextBlock>
</xbrl>

<DOCUMENT>
<TYPE>EX-10
<SEQUENCE>8
<FILENAME>10-16resshar.htm
<TEXT>
<HTML>

EXHIBIT 10.16
<h2>
BALTIA AIR LINES, INC.<p>
BOARD RESOLUTION
</h2>
<P>
Board meeting was held on April 12, 2013.  The following resolutions were passed unanimously:
<p>1. Resolved that, Board affirms the individual agreements not to sell shares issued for compensation to the following officers: Igor Dmitrowsky, Barry Clare, Russell Thal, Andris Rukmanis, and Walter Kaplinsky, entered into by the officers and Baltia Air Lines. The underlying agreement not to sell will continue to be effective until such time that Baltia had received its Air Carrier Certificate and commenced revenue flight operations, and may be further extended by the consenting parties.
<p>
2. Resolved, that Board reaffirms its Board resolution of December 18, 2001, that the Company cannot pay its President Igor Dmitrowsky, and that to provide incentive, the Company will continue to pay  for reasonable expenses including travel, meals, lodging, limited entertainment, and automobile.
<p>
/signed/  Walter Kaplinsky<br>
Corporate Secretary
<p>

/signed/ Igor Dmitrowsky        4-12-13<br>
Director			     Date
</P>

<p>
/signed/ Andris Rukmanis         4-12-13<br>
Director			       Date
<p>


/signed/ Luis Bolanos                 4/12/2013      <br>
Director			        Date
</p>
</html>
</TEXT>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<TYPE>EX-3
<SEQUENCE>9
<FILENAME>3.1.1_CertArtclesIncop.htm
<TEXT>
<HTML>
<BODY>
<H3>EXHIBIT 3.1.1 - Articles of Incorporation (as amended Nov 2, 201X)</h3>
<hr>
<STRONG>
<P ALIGN= Center>Certificate of Incorporation of<BR> BALTIA AIR LINES, INC. <BR><BR>
</STRONG>
under Section 402 of the Business Corporation Law
</P>

<P>
IT IS HEREBY CERTIFIED THAT:

</P>

<P>(1)
The name of the proposed corporation is BALTIA AIR LINES, INC.

</P>

<P>(2)
 The purposes for which this corporation is formed are as follows, to wit:


</P>

<P>To engage in any lawful act or activity for which corporations may be organized under the Business Corporation Law. The corporation is not formed to engage in any act or activity requiring the consent or approval of any state official, department, board, agency or other body.
</P>

<P>To engage in air transport and related services.
</P>

<P>The corporation, in furtherance of its corporate purposes set forth, shall have all of the powers enumerated in Section 203 of the Business Corporation Law, subject to any limitations provided in the Business Corporation Law or any other statute of the State of New York.

</P>

<P>(3)
 The office of the corporation is to be located in the City of New York, County of Queens, State of New York.

</P>

<P>(4)
The aggregate number of shares which the corporation shall have the authority to issue is 1,500,000,000 common shares ($.0001 par value) and 2,000,000 preferred shares ($.01 par value). Shareholders do not have preemptive rights.

</P>

<P>(5)
 The Secretary of State is designated as agent of the corporation upon which process against it may be served.  The post office address to which the Secretary of State shall mail a copy of any process against the corporation served upon him is

</P>

<P ALIGN=CENTER>63-65 Saunders Street, Suite 7I Rego Park, NY 11374

</P>

<P>The undersigned incorporator or each of them is there are more than one, is of the age of eighteen year or over.

</P>

<P>[As amended by Certificate of Amendment under Section 805 of Business Corporation Law by corporation's Board and Written Consent of Shareholders on 10/21/2010, signed and notarized on October 31, 2010 by Igor Dmitrowsky as President and CEO of the corporation, and filed with the State of New York Department of State on November 2, 2010, 101102000702]
</P>
</BODY>
</HTML>

</TEXT>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>

<SEQUENCE>10
<FILENAME>3.1.2_CertArtclesIncop.htm

<BODY>
<H3>EXHIBIT 3.1.2 - Articles of Incorporation (as amended June 24, 2011)</h3>
<hr>
<STRONG>
<P ALIGN= Center>CERTIFICATE OF AMENDMENT<br> of the<BR> CERTIFICATE OF INCORPORATION OF BALTIA AIR LINES, INC. <BR><BR>
</STRONG>
under Section 805 of the Business Corporation Law
</P>

<P>
IT IS HEREBY CERTIFIED THAT:

</P>

<P>(1)
The name of the corporation is BALTIA AIR LINES, INC.

</P>

<P>(2)
The filing date of the corporation's certificate of incorporation is: 8/24/89.


</P>

<p>(3)
The corporation requests that the number of its authorized common shares be increased to 2,000,000,000 amending article 4 to state as follows:

<P>
(4)
     The aggregate number of shares which the corporation shall have the authority to issue is 2,000,000,000 common shares ($.0001 par value) and 2,000,000 preferred shares ($.01 par value). Shareholders do not have preemptive rights.

</P>

<P>(4)
The amendment of the certificate of incorporation was authorized:

by the corporation's board of directors and by a vote of the majority of all outstanding shares entitled to vote at a meeting on 06/24/2011

<PRE>
State of New York        )
                         )ss.
County of Queens         )
</PRE>
I, Igor Dmitrowsky, being duly sworn, depose and state that I am the President and C.E.O. of Baltia Air Lines, Inc., the corporation named in the described above in the foregoing certificate and that I have read the foregoing certificate and know the contents thereof to be true, except as to the matters herein stated to be alleged upon information and belief, and as those matters, I believe them to be true.
<p>
/signed/<br>
Igor Dmitrowsky
</p>
<p>
Sworn to me this 24th day of June, 2011
<p>
/signed/<br>
Notary Public
<p>
IN WITNESS WHEREOF, this certificate had been subscribed this 24th day of June, 2011, by the undersigned who affirms that the statements herein are true under the penalty of perjiury
</p>

<p>/signed/<br>
Igor Dmitrowsky

</p>
<p>
PAULA A. JOSLYN DOSSO<br>
NOTARY PUBLIC, State of New York<br>
No. 01JO6192435<br>
Qualified in Kings County<br>

<DOCUMENT>
<TYPE>EX-10
<SEQUENCE>13
<FILENAME>10-13_151rent.htm
<TEXT>
<HTML></p>

<P><H1 ALIGN=CENTER>Japan Airlines Management Corp. (JMC)
<p>
As
<p>
Sublessor
<p>
and </p>

<P>Sublessee </p>
<P>
BALTIA AIR LINES
<p>
SUBLEASE AGREEMENT </p>

<P></h1>
<CENTER>
<H3>
Effective: on or about September 1, 2011
<br>Termination: November 30, 2015 </h3>

<P>1 </p>

<P><HR>
<h2 ALIGN=CENTER></p>

<P>SUBLEASE AGREEMENT
</h2>

</CENTER>
<P>

THIS AGREEMENT OF SUBLEASE made as of this 1st day of June 2011 by and between
Japan Airlines
Management Corp. (the "Sublessor") a New York corporation, having and place of business at
Building No. 14,
John F. Kennedy International Airport (the "Airport"), in the County of Queens, City and State of
New York
and Baltia Air Lines (the "Sublessee") a New York Corporation having its principal office at
Building 151
Room 361 JFK Inti Airport, Jan1aica, NY 11430 </p>

<P ALIGN=CENTER>WITNESSETH </p>

<P>WHEREAS, Sublessor is the tenant under a certain Agreement of Lease between the Port
Authority of
New York and New Jersey ("the Port Authority") Lease No. A YB-970 (as the same may
hereafter be amended,
the "Lease") dated June 4, 1991 and covering certain premises at Building No, 14, John F.
Kennedy
International Airport and as more particularly described in said Lease. </p>

<P>WHEREAS, by sublease dated June 4, 1991 (the "Master Sublease"), Sublessor subleased to
Japan
Airlines Company, Ltd. (together with its successors and assigns, "JAL") a certain portion of the
Site, which is
called as Building No. 151 and Building No. 14, as described therein (hereinafter referred to as
the "JAL
Premises"); </p>

<P>WHEREAS, by sublease dated as of June 1, 1991 (the "Company Sublease"), JAL subleased
to the New
York City Industrial Development Agency (the "IDA") the entire JAL Premises; </p>

<P>WHEREAS, by sublease dated as of June 1, 1991 (the "IDA Sublease"), the IDA then
Subleased back to JAL the entire JAL Premises; </p>

<P>WHEREAS, by sublease dated as of September 1, 1991 (the "JMC Sublease"), JAL
subleased back
to Sublessor a portion of the J AL Premises as described therein (as the same may change
pursuant to the terms
of JMC Sublease, the "JMC Premises"); and </p>

<P>WHEREAS, Sublessee desires to lease certain space at said .TMC Premises from the
Sublessor. </p>

<P>NOW, THEREFORE, in consideration of the rents, covenants and mutual agreements
hereinafter
contained, Sublessor and Sublessee hereby covenant and agree as follows: </p>

<P>1. Subletting. Sublessor hereby sublets to Sublessee and the Sublessee hereby hires and takes
from the
Sublessor certain office space located on the 2"d floor of approximately 9,219 rentable square
feet and 2672
rentable sf of aircraft maintenance space in Bldg 151 subject to the terms and conditions of the
Lease.
</p>
<P>
2. Term. The term of this Sublease shall commence, subject to the consent of the Port Authority,
on
September 1, 2011, (the "Commencement Date") and, unless earlier terminated by either party as
herein
provided or unless extended in accordance with Section 52 hereof, and shall terminate on
November 30, 2105.
Not withstanding the foregoing, either party shall have the right to terminate this Sublease for
any reason (24)
months after Commencement Date by giving notice of such termination sixty (60) days prior to
such Early
Termination Date; provided however, that if the Sublease is terminated by the Port Authority for
any reason
whatsoever prior to said expiration date, this Sublease shall thereupon terminate on the day
proceeding such
3 </p>

<P>

termination by the Port Authority. </p>

<P>3. Rent. The Sublessee agrees to pay to Sublessor Base Rental at the rate of$ 324,029.75 per
annum as
more particularly described in Appendix I, in lawful money of the United States, in equal
monthly installments
in advance of the first day of each and every calendar month for the period September 1, 20 11 to
August 31,
2012. Effective September 1, 2012 and thereafter the rent will be increased 4% per year on the
first day of
September of each year.
 </p>

<P>4. Use. The sublease shall be bound by and subject to the terms, covenants, conditions and
provisions of
the Lease as to Sublessee's occupancy and use of the Subleased Premises under this Sublease
Sublessee agrees to and shall use the Subleased Premises for the following purposes and
activities only: </p>

<P>(a)
As to the office space:
</p><p>(i)
Business and administrative offices in connection with Sublessee's business.
</p><p>(ii)
For the training ofpersonnel employed or to be employed by Sublessee in
connection with Sublessee's operation.
</p><p>(iii)
Any other lawful purpose which does not conflict with the Lease.
</p><p>(b)
Access to the Subleased Premises, subject to the provisions of paragraph 43 of this
Sublease.
</p><p>(i)
For the parking of automobiles operated by officers, employees and
business invitees of Sublessee in connection with all purposes and
activities defmed in this Section 4. </p>

<P></p><p>(ii)
Sublessee will have access to the Subleased Premises twenty-four hours, seven
days a week.

</p>
<P>
5. Alterations. Sublessee has accepted the Subleased Premises for occupancy in their present
condition. Any other work required to prepare the Subleased premises for occupancy shall be
prepared and
completed by Sublessee at its sole cost and expense. Sublessee, however shall not make any
modifications or
alterations on the Subleased Premises without prior written consent of the Sublessor. Any and all
such
alterations and modifications shall be made at the sole cost and expense of Sublessee.
</p>
<P>

6.
Services.
</p><p>(a)
Electricity and Gas.
</p><p>(i) As long as Sublessee is not in default under any provision of this Sublease,
Sublessor shall make available reasonable quantities of electricity and gas for usage by the
Sublessee in the
Subleased Premises, to the extent made available to Sublessor by the Port Authority, or
otherwise.
</p><p>(ii) Such electricity and gas used by Sublessee shall be metered or sub-metered by the
Port Authority or other supplier and Sublessee shall be billed directly by the Port Authority or
other supplier for
such consumption of gas and electricity; provided, however, should such electricity or gas not be
metered or
4 </p>

<P>

sub-metered, Sublessee shall pay Sublessor its Pro Rata Share of consumption thereof. </p>

<P></p><p>(b) Water. To the extent furnished and supplied by the Port Authority or other supplier, the
Sublessor shall furnish and supply cold water in reasonable quantities for use by Sublessee in the
Subleased
Premises. Sublessee shall pay Sublessor promptly its Pro Rata Share of the cost of such water, as
charged and
billed by the Port Authority.
</p><p>(c) Sewerage. Sewerage service as furnished by the City of New Y ark. The Sublessee shall
pay Sublessor promptly its Pro Rata Share of charges imposed or assessed against the Port
Authority and
charged to the Sublessor with respect to the use and occupancy of the Leased Premises of which
the Subleased
Premises form a part.
</p><p>(d) Heating. Ventilation, and Air Conditioning The Sublessor shall furnish and supply heating,
ventilation and air conditioning ("HV AC") in reasonable quantities for use by Sublessee in the
Subleased
Premises. The HVAC will be available twenty-four hours per day, seven days per week. Cost is
included as part
of the electricity and gas cost.
Neither the Sublessor nor the Port Authority shall be under any obligation to supply utility
services
under (a) and (b) above, if and to the extent and during any period that supplying of any such
service or the use
of any component necessary therefore shall be prohibited or rationed by any federal, state or
municipal law,
rule, regulation, requirement, order or direction and if the Port Authority deems it in the public
interest to
comply therewith, even though such law, rule, regulation, requirement, order or direction may
not be mandatory
on the Port Authority as a public agency. </p>

<P>No failure, delay or interruption in making the foregoing utility services available (whether
or not a
separate charge is made therefore) shall be or be construed to be an eviction of the Sublessee or
grounds for any
diminution or abatement of rental or (unless resulting from the negligence or willful failure of the
Sublessor or
the Port Authority) shall be grounds for any claims by the Sublessee for damages, consequential
or otherwise. </p>

<P>7. Obligations of Sublessee.
 </p>

<P>essee shall conduct its operations hereunder in an orderly and proper manner, so
as not to unreasonably annoy, disturb or be offensive to others at or off the Airport. The
Sublessee shall take all
reasonable measures to eliminate vibrations originating on the Subleased Premises tending to
damage any
equipment, structure, building or portion of a building which is on the Subleased Premises,
 </p>

<P>essee shall use its best efforts to conduct all its operations at the Subleased
Premises in a safe and careful manner.
 </p>

<P>r and the Port Authority shall have the right to object to the Sublessee regarding
the conduct and demeanor of the employees of the Sublessee whereupon the Sublessee will take
all steps
reasonably necessary to remove the cause of the objection. If requested by the Port Authority the
Sublessee
shall supply and shall require its employees to wear or carry badges or other suitable means of
identification,
which shall be subject to the prior and continuing approval of the General Manager of the
Airport.
 </p>

<P>Lessee shall take all necessary measures to adopt and maintain strict security
measures with respect to all its operations in and about the Subleased Premises and in this
respect shall maintain
such security in accordance with Sublessee's own internal regulations, the rules and regulations
of Sublessor,
the Port Authority and such governmental agencies as may have jurisdiction. Such security
measures taken in
and about the Subleased Premises shall be performed by Sublessee's personnel or by a contractor
duly approved
by the Port Authority to perform cargo security services. Expenses arising from such security
measure shall be
at the sole expense of Sublessee. Notwithstanding the foregoing Sublessee shall also pay
Sublessor its Pro Rata
Share of security and security maintenance expenses undertaken by Sublessor with respect to
common areas of
the Leased Premises as required under Section II, hereof. </p>

<P>(e) The Sublessee shall remove from the Airport or otherwise dispose of, in a manner
approved by the General Manager of the Airport, all garbage, debris, and other waste materials
(whether solid
or liquid) arising out of the occupancy of the Subleased Premises or out of operations at the
Subleased
Premises. Any such solid waste which may be temporarily stored in the open, shall be kept in
suitable garbage
and waste receptacles, the same to be made of metal or other suitable material, and equipped with
tight fitting
covers, and to be of a safe and proper design in order to contain whatever material may be placed
therein. The
Sublessee shall use extreme care when removing all such waste materials, and shall effect such
removal at such
times and by such means as provided by the Port Authority. No such garbage, debris, or other
waste materials
shall or be permitted to be thrown, discharged or deposited into or upon the waters at or
bounding the Airport.
 </p>

<P>(f) In addition to compliance by the Sublessee with all laws, ordinances, governmental rules,
regulations and orders now or at any time in effect during the term of the subletting hereunder
which as a matter
of law are applicable to the operation, use or maintenance by the Sublessee of the Subleased
Premises or the
operations of the Sublessee under this Sublease (except as otherwise specifically provided
herein), Sublessee
agrees that it shall exercise the highest degree of safety and care and shall conduct all its
operations under the
Sublease and shall operate, use and maintain the Subleased Premises in accordance with the
highest standards in
the air transportation industry and in such manner that there will be at all times a minimum of air
pollution,
water pollution or any other type of pollution and a minimum of noise emanating from, arising
out of or
resulting from the operation, use or maintenance of the Subleased Premises by the Sublessee and
from the
operations of the Sublessee under this Sublease, considering the highest standards in the air
transportation
industry.
</p>
<P>
8. Prohibited Acts.
 </p>

<P>(a) The Sublessee shall commit no unlawful nuisance, waste or injury on the Subleased
Premises and shall not do or permit to be done anything which may result in the creation or
commission or
maintenance of such nuisance, waste or injury on the Subleased Premises.
 </p>

<P>(b) The Sublessee shall not create nor permit to be caused or created upon the Subleased
Premises, any obnoxious odors or smokes, or noxious gases or vapors. The creation of exhaust
fumes by the
operation of internal-combustion engines, so long as such engines are maintained and are being
operated in a
proper manner, shall not be a violation ofthis paragraph (b).
 </p>

<P>(c) The Sublessee shall not do or permit to be done anything which may interfere with the
effectiveness or accessibility of the drainage and sewerage system, water system,
communications system, fuel
system, electrical, fire-protection system, sprinkler system, alarm system, fire hydrants and hoses
and other
systems, if any, installed or located on, under, or in the Subleased Premises. Any construction
work being performed by the Sublessee pursuant to and in accordance with Section 5 hereof will not be
deemed a violation
of the foregoing, but the same shall not relieve or release the Sublessee from its responsibility of
making the
aforesaid systems accessible and of not interfering with said systems. </p>

<P>(d) The Sublessee shall not do or permit to be done any act or thing upon the Subleased
Premises (1) which will invalidate or conflict with any fire insurance, extended coverage or
rental insurance
policies covering the Subleased Premises or any part thereof, or the Airport or any part thereof,
or (2) which in
the opinion of the Port Authority, may constitute an extra hazardous condition, so as to increase
the risks
normally attendant upon the operations contemplated by or mentioned in Section 4 hereof. The
Sublessee shall
promptly observe, comply with the provisions of any and all present and future rules and
regulations,
requirements, orders and directions of The National Board of Fire Underwriters and the Fire
Rating
Organization of New York, or of any other board or organization exercising or which may
exercise similar
functions, which may pertain or apply to the operations of the Sublessee on the Subleased
Premises, and the
Sublessee shall, subject to and in accordance with the provisions of Section 9 and ll hereof, make
any and all
structural and non-structural improvements, alterations or repairs of the Subleased Premises
required at any
time hereafter by any such present or future rule, regulation, requirement, order or direction. If by
reason of
any failure on the part of the Sublessee to comply with the provisions of this paragraph any fire
insurance rate,
extended coverage or rental insurance rate on the Subleased Premises or any part thereof, or on
the Airport or
any part thereof, shall at any time be higher than it would be if the Subleased Premises were
properly used for
the purposes permitted by Section 4 hereof, then the Sublessee shall pay to the Sublessor, as an
item of
additional rental, that part of all insurance premiums paid by the Port Authority which shall have
been charged
because of such violation or failure by the Sublessee.
</p><p>(e) The Sublessee shall not dispose of nor permit any one to dispose of any waste material
</p><p>(whether liquid or solid) by means of the toilets, manholes, sanitary sewers or storm sewers in the
Subleased
Premises or on the Airport except after treatment in installations or equipment included in plans
and
specifications submitted to and approved by the Port Authority.
</p><p>(f) The Sublessee shall not keep or store during any 24-hour period flrnnmable liquids within
any enclosed portion of the Subleased Premises (other than in rooms or areas expressly
constructed for the
storage of such liquids) in excess of the Sublessee's working requirements during the said
24-hour period. Any
such liquids having a flash point of less than ll0 F shall be kept and stored in safety containers of
a type
approved by the Underwriters Laboratories or the Factory Mutual Insurance Association.
</p><p>(g) The Sublessee shall not operate any engine or any item of automotive equipment in any
enclosed space on the Subleased Premises unless such space is adequately ventilated and unless
such engine or
item of automotive equipment is equipped with a proper spark arresting device which has been
approved by the
Port Authority.
</p><p>(h) The Sublessee shall not install, maintain or operate, or permit the installation,
maintenance or operation on the Subleased Premises of any vending-machine or device designed
to dispense or
sell food, beverages, tobacco, tobacco products or merchandise of any kind whether or not
included in the above
categories, or of any restaurant, cafeteria, kitchen, stand or other establishment of any type for the
preparation
or dispensing of food. beverages, tobacco, tobacco products, or merchandise of any kind whether
or not
included in the above categories, or of any equipment or devices for the furnishing to the public
of service of
any kind including therein, without limitation thereto, telephone pay stations.

</p><p>(i) The Sublessee shall not overload any floor and shall repair any floor, including
supporting members, and any paved area damaged by overloading. Nothing in this paragraph (i)
or elsewhere
in this Sublease shall be or be construed to be a representation by the Port Authority of the
weight any floor will
bear.
G) The Sublessee shall not fuel or defuel its automotive vehicles or other equipment in any
enclosed portions of the Subleased Premises. </p>

<P>(k) The Sublessee shall not use any cleaning materials having a harmful corrosive effect on
any part of the Subleased Premises.
</p><p>(I) The Sublessee shall not use or permit the use of any truss or structural supporting
member of the building or roof or any part thereof of any building on the Subleased Premises for
the storage of
any material or equipment, or to hoist, lift, move or support any material or equipment, or other
weight or load,
by means of said trusses or structural supporting members.
 </p>

<P>9. Compliance with Governmental Requirements.
</p><p>(a) Subject to the Lease, the Sublessee shall comply with all laws and ordinances and
governmental rules, regulations and orders now or at any time during the term of this Sublease,
which as a
matter of law are applicable to or which afiect the operations of the Sublessee at the Subleased
Premises
hereunder or the occupancy or use of the Subleased Premises.
</p><p>(b) The Sublessee shall procure from all governmental authorities having jurisdiction over
the operations of the Sublessee hereunder and shall maintain in full force and effect throughout
the term of this
Sublease all licenses, certificates, permits or other authorization which may be necessary for the
conduct of such
operations. "Governmental authority" shall not be construed as intending to include The Port
Authority of New
York and New Jersey, under this Sublease.
</p><p>(c) The obligation of the Sublessee to comply with governmental requirements with respect
to the Subleased Premises is provided herein for the purpose of assuring proper safeguards for
the protection of
persons and property on the Subleased Premises. Such provision is not to be construed as a
submission by the
Port Authority to the application to itself of such requirements or any of them.
</p><p>(d) The Sublessee shall pay all license, certification, permit and examination fees, duties,
excises, taxes and all other governmental charges of every character, present and future, which
may be assessed,
levied, exacted or imposed on the Sublessee's property, operations or occupancy hereunder or on
any property
whatsoever which may be received at the Subleased Premises or on the gross receipts, rental or
income there
from including any penalties or interest thereon and any taxes on personal property which may be
assessed,
levied, exacted, or imposed, and the Sublessee shall make all applications and reports required in
connection
therewith. If any bond or other undertaking shall be required by any governmental authority in
connection with
any of the operations of the Sublessee or any property received or exhibited by the Sublessee at
the Subleased
Premises, the Sublessee shall furuish the same and pay all expenses in connection therewith. The
Sublessee
shall also pay any and all franchise, excise and other taxes, fees and other charges assessed,
levied or imposed
on the Sublessee. No alleged or purported immunity or exemption from any taxes or fees
described in this
paragraph available to the Port Authority shall be grounds for or excuse non-payment thereof by
the Sublessee. </p>

<P>(e) The Sublessee shall pay its Pro Rata Share of any and all real estate taxes, if any, or any
other tax, assessment, levy, fee or charge, general or special, ordinary or extraordinary, foreseen
or unforeseen,
of whatever nature or kind which during the term of the subletting hereunder may be levied,
assessed, imposed
